INTERNATIONAL

Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz are negotiating a plan of ''intensive cooperation'' in automobile technology, aerospace, microelectronics and a number of service industries. It may prove to be one of the most far-reaching industrial linkups ever and could pose an enormous competitive challenge for the U.S. [Page A1.] The talks between the giant industrial groups are an attempt by both companies to position themselves before the European Community forms a single, borderless market by the end of 1992, analysts said. [D5.]
The Soviet Parliament approved a property law giving private citizens the right to own small-scale factories and other businesses for the first time since the 1920's. [A1.]
THE ECONOMY
Orders received by the nation's factories fell in January at the steepest rate in 15 years, the Commerce Department said, reflecting a slump in the nation's manufacturing sector. [D1.]
The Postal Service proposed an increase in all classes of mail that would raise a first-class stamp to 30 cents. [A16.]
COMPANIES
Some restrictions on A.T.&T. should be removed, the F.C.C. chairman said, because enough competition exists. [D1.]
Perrier is returning - today in France and by early April in America. A big marketing challenge lies ahead. [D1.]
The Commerce Department is reworking proposed rules that would ease restrictions on exports of high-performance computers, agency officials said. [D2.]
De Beers Consolidated Mines will split itself in two and base one of the newly formed companies in Switzerland. [D4.]

Time Warner announced a joint venture with the Soviet film industry to build movie theaters in Moscow and Leningrad [D8] . The company will also start the country's first children's book club, offering a monthly selection of reading. [D17.]
The Sunday Correspondent, seen as a likely casualty in Britain's ''quality'' Sunday newspaper war, announced new financing and a new shareholder. [D20.]
Centaur Partners, in its effort to control National Intergroup, made two proposals that will ease its way. [D4.]
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
Sports cars and automatic transmissions have never mixed well. Porsche hopes to change all that. [D6.]
A robot that can vacuum office buildings without assistance has been developed by a Canadian inventor. [D6.]
MARKETS
A decline in bond yields helped push stocks higher, with the Dow industrials advancing 27.25 points, to 2,676.80. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange remained relatively light. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in thin trading, as many dealers who sold on Monday became buyers. [D14.]
The dollar closed mostly higher in domestic trading after falling overseas in the absence of any major developments to move the foreign exchange markets. [D15.]
Most livestock and meat futures rose strongly on the Chicago Merc, helped by short-term demand and favorable shipping weather. Soybeans soared, grains were mixed and coffee fell. [D15.]
TODAY'S COLUMNS
''New'' Coke will get a new name and will take on Pepsi, Coca-Cola confirmed. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D1.]
Cutting ''greenhouse effect'' gases in the U.S. just 20 percent would cost trillions of dollars, two economists say, but that's not the really bad news. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Investors have abandoned stocks of many debt-laden companies, but this may have left some good buys. Market Place. [D8.]
